name: Erythrokeratoderma Variabilis et Progressiva (EKVP)
chief_complaint: My skin has patches that keep changing color and texture, and they're spreading.
physical_findings: Sharply demarcated red patches with variable borders
Thickened, scaly plaques in fixed locations (e.g., elbows, knees)
Lesions that wax and wane in size and shape over hours to days

lab_results.Skin biopsy: Hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and mild perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate
lab_results.Genetic testing: Mutation in GJB3 or GJB4 (connexin genes)

prognosis: Chronic condition with variable course; lesions may stabilize in adulthood but rarely resolve completely
description: EKVP is a rare genodermatosis characterized by two distinct features: (1) transient, migratory erythematous patches (variabilis) and (2) fixed hyperkeratotic plaques (progressiva). It results from mutations affecting gap junction proteins. The condition typically presents in infancy or early childhood.
